results.title: L'atalante [study extract]
results.brief_description: An extract from the last film directed by Jean Vigo, which tells the story of a young skipper of a barge who takes on board his newly-wed country girl, and their slow trip up the Seine towards Paris. The film relates their early love, disillusion, separation and final reconciliation. This extract deals with their separation. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: L'associe = the Associate
results.brief_description:
Julien Pardot, a rather dull corporate executive invents an ‘assistant’, the dynamic, go-getting ‘Mr. Davis’ on whom all the important decisions depend. Pretending to be Mr. Davis’ intermediary, Pardot at last makes it big in the business world. A crisis develops when Pardot’s investors demand to meet Mr. Davis in person—and when several young ladies show up, claiming to be the mothers of Mr. Davis’ children. Re-made as ‘The Associate’ (1996), with Whoopie Goldberg. Both are a re-makes of the 1939 film ‘The Mysterious Mr. Davis’ directed by Claude Autant-Lara with a cast of British actors, including Alastair Sim.

Credits: Producer, Simone Allouche ; director, Rene Gainville ; writers, Rene Gainville, Jean-Claude Carriere ; photography, Etienne Szabo ; music, Michel Bernholc, Mort Schuman.
Cast: Michel Serrault, Claudine Auger, Catherine Alric, Judith Magre, Henri Virlojeux, Mathieu Carriere.

results.title: L'assassin Habite Au 21 = the Killer Is at No. 21
results.brief_description:
A murder takes place at a boarding house full of eccentrics, each one a likely suspect. Clouzot, whose films are generally dark in character, made his feature debut with this delightful comedy-thriller of ‘The Thin Man’ type. The films is not one of these intimidating masterpieces that mark the history of [French] cinema. It is an unpretentious and entertaining piece, solidly built around 2 main centers of interest: the sarcastic and spicy exploration of a boarding house and the colourful fauna living inside it”. Reference: Le Nouvel Observateur, 3 April 1987. German censorship had all the scenes featuring Linz’s interrogation cut out of the film because they were judged too violent. Clouzot had asked the actors playing the police not to fake the action and actor Noel Roquevert who plays Linz finished the scene with a swollen face.

Credits: Director, Henri-Georges Clouzot ; writer, Henri-Georges Clouzot ; photography, Armand Thirard ; music, Maurice Yvain.
Cast: Pierre Fresnay, Suzy Delair, Pierre Larquey, Noel Roquevert, Jean Tissier, Louis Florencie, Raymond Bussieres, Odette Talazac, Marc Natol, Huguette Vivier.

results.title: L'armee Roulante = the Rolling Army
results.brief_description:
Vidocq, Annette and friend are travelling with brand new IDs. What they don’t know is that the man who sold the papers to them works for Flambart and that their new identities belong to two army deserters.

Credits: Producer, Etienne Laroche ; director, Marcel Bluwal ; writer, Georges Neveux ; photography, Maurice Damien ; music, Serge Gainsbourg.
Cast: Bernard Noel, Alain Mottet, Genevieve Fontanel, Jacques Alric, Jacques Aveline, Jaxques Rispal, Martin Trevieres.

results.title: L'armee des Ombres = the Shadow Army
results.brief_description:
Melville adopted the thriller format for his account of the Resistance. It can be regarded as the third instalment of a trilogy about life in France under German occupation started with ‘Le silence de la mer’ (1949) and ‘Leon Morin, pretre’ (1961), both held in our collection. Far from the usual romantic cliches showing handsome young men playing tricks with the Nazis and falling in love with sublime women, the substance of the movie is reality. It depicts a ‘shadow army’ made of courageous men who are ready to sacrifice their lives but are aware of the huge cost they will eventually have to pay. It shows the cruel and sometimes inhuman choices they have to make in order to survive. Both writer Joseph Kessel and co-writer and director Jean-Pierre Melville belonged to this ‘Army in the shadows’. Andre Dewavrin (known as Colonel Passy in the Resistance) plays himself.

Credits: Producer, Jacques Dorfmann ; director, Jean-Pierre Melville ; writer, Jean-Pierre Melville ; photography, Pierre Lhomme, Walter Wottitz ; music, Eric Demarsan.
Cast: Lino Ventura, Simone Signoret, Paul Meurisse, Jean-Pierre Cassel, Nathalie Delon, Paul Crauchet, Claude Mann, Christian Barbier, Serge Reggiani, Alain Mottet, Andre Dewavrin.

results.title: L'argent des Autres = Other People's Money
results.creator_credit: Michelle de Broca, Henri Lassa, Adolphe Viezzi and Christian de Chalonge
results.brief_description:
Henri Rainier, a bank director, is unwillingly implicated in a financial fraud and laid off. Convinced he is being set up by others in the bank, he decides to investigate a number of dubious transactions and discovers a vast real estate swindle. Awards: Prix Louis Delluc, 1978 ; French Academy of Cinema (Cesars) 1978: Best Director for Christian de Chalonge, Best Film.

Credits: Producers, Michelle de Broca, Henri Lassa, Adolphe Viezzi ; director, Christian de Chalonge ; writers, Pierre Dumayet, Christian de Chalonge ; photography, Jean-Louis Picavet ; music, Patrice Mestral.
Cast: Jean-Louis Trintignant, Claude Brasseur, Michel Serrault, Catherine Deneuve, Juliet Berto, Francois Perrot.

results.title: L'argent = Money
results.creator_credit: Jean-Pierre Baste, Patricia Moraz and Robert Bresson
results.brief_description:
A single forged banknote changes hands as a schoolboy prank and follows a remorseless path (the chain reaction of Tolstoy’s novella) which culminates in murder. Bresson ignores sociological and psychological explanation in austerely charting the paradoxical path of crime and punishment which leads the murderer towards redemption. Further reading: Film Comment. ‘Special Bresson’. May/June and July 1999

Credits: Producer, Jean-Pierre Baste, Patricia Moraz ; director, writer, Robert Bresson ; photography, Emmanuel Manchuel, Pasqualino de Santis ; music, Jean-Sebastien Bach ; editor, Jean-Francois Naudon.
Cast: Christian Patey, Caroline Lang, Silvie van den Elsen, Vincent Risterucci.

results.title: L'apprenti Salaud = the Apprentice Heel
results.brief_description:
Antoine was a pleasant and agreeable man for years, until a small inheritance begins to give him some dangerous ideas about gaining wealth and women. Partly in order to win the affections of a young woman, he becomes a small-time con man on the basis of some ideas his accountant has planted in his mind.

Credits: Producer, Philippe Dussart ; director, Michel Deville ; writer, Michel Deville ; photography, Claude Lecomte ; music, Georges Bizet.
Cast: Robert Lamoureux, Christine Dejoux, Claude Pieplu, Georges Wilson, Jean-Pierre Kalfon, Jacques Doniol-Valcroze, Jean-Francois Derec, Bernard Lavalette, Annick Blancheteau.

results.title: L'annee Derniere a Marienbad = Last Year in Marienbad (Cinemascope Print)
results.creator_credit: Pierre Courau, Raymond Froment and Alain Resnais
results.brief_description:
Robbe-Grillet described ‘Marienbad’ as ‘the story of a persuading’ centred on a romantic triangle ending in violence, constructed in the mind of X, one of the three. To Resnais, ‘Marienbad’ looks like a statue and sounds like an opera’. The images of the chateau are those of a labyrinth of fake trails, variants, failures and repetitions, destroying spatial and temporal logic in a film about the processes of memory that locates everything in the present tense. In keeping with Robbe-Grillet’s rejection of conventional interior monologue the emphasis is not on what X is thinking and feeling but on what he ‘sees’. With a hint of playfulness Resnais’ treatment of Robbe-Grillet’s script suggests a meditation on narrative tyranny, a modernist demonstration of narrative cinema as process: instead of the image revealing the world, it reveals itself. Awards: Best Film Venice Film Festival (Mostra) 1961 ; Prix Georges Melies 1961 ; Prix Andre Bazin 1961.

Credits: Producers, Pierre Courau, Raymond Froment ; director, Alain Resnais ; writer, Alain Robbe-Grillet ; photography, Sacha Vierny ; music, Francis Seyrig ; art direction, Jacques Saulnier ; assistant director, Volker Schloendorff.
Cast: Giorgio Albertazzi, Delphine Seyrig, Sacha Pitoeff.

results.title: L'Ange
results.creator_credit: INA France, Kira BM Films and Patrick Bokanowski
results.brief_description: This amazing marriage of art, music and film took five years (1977-1982) in the making by its French creator, Patrick Bokanowski and programmed non-stop in a Tokyo cinema for nearly ten years. The impressionistic images are accompanied by a beautiful atmospheric soundtrack of original music composed by Michele Bokanowski to present a textured, multi-layered complexity of vision and sound. “L’Ange” makes for compelling viewing and deserves its cult status in the world of avant-garde filmmaking. Cast includes Jacques Faure, Martine Couture, Jean-Marie Bon, Dominique Lesourd, Maurice Baquet, Rita Renoir, Patricia Peretti.
